concepts.concept_name: Standard units of measurement and SI system
History of transport and evolution of measurement

in_scope: Types of motion: rectilinear, circular, rotational, periodic, oscillatory
Objects can exhibit more than one type of motion simultaneously
Need for standard units of measurement
SI unit of length: metre (m)
Commonly used units: millimetre, centimetre, metre, kilometre
Conversion between units of length
Measuring length using ruler, metre scale, measuring tape
Correct way to read a scale (avoiding parallax error)
History of transport: from walking to modern vehicles
Evolution from body-based measurements to standard units
out_of_scope: Acceleration and equations of motion — Class 9
Vernier caliper and screw gauge measurements — Class 8-9

in_scope: Light travels in a straight line (rectilinear propagation)
Luminous objects: produce their own light (sun, candle, bulb)
Non-luminous objects: do not produce their own light (moon, table)
Transparent objects: allow light to pass through completely (glass, water)
Translucent objects: allow light to pass partially (frosted glass, oiled paper)
Opaque objects: do not allow light to pass through (wood, metal)
Conditions for shadow formation: light source, opaque object, screen
Characteristics of shadows: always dark, shape depends on object and angle
Reflection of light from a plane mirror
Image in a plane mirror: erect, same size, laterally inverted
Pinhole camera: construction, working, image characteristics
out_of_scope: Laws of reflection in detail — Class 7-8
Curved mirrors and image formation — Class 8
Speed of light and electromagnetic spectrum — Class 8-9

in_scope: Electric cell: source of electricity, has two terminals (positive and negative)
Battery: combination of two or more cells
Electric circuit: closed path for current to flow
Components of a simple circuit: cell, wire, bulb, switch
Drawing circuit diagrams using symbols
Electric current flows from positive to negative terminal
Conductors: materials that allow electricity to pass through (metals, water)
Insulators: materials that do not allow electricity to pass (rubber, plastic, wood)
Electric switch: device to open or close a circuit
Open circuit: broken path, current does not flow, bulb does not glow
Closed circuit: complete path, current flows, bulb glows
out_of_scope: Ohm's law and resistance calculations — Class 8-9
Series and parallel circuit calculations — Class 8

concepts.concept_name: Poles of a magnet and compass

in_scope: Discovery of magnets: magnetite (lodestone) as a natural magnet
Artificial magnets: bar magnet, horseshoe magnet, cylindrical magnet
Magnets attract magnetic materials (iron, nickel, cobalt)
Non-magnetic materials are not attracted (wood, plastic, rubber)
Every magnet has two poles: North pole and South pole
Like poles repel, unlike poles attract
A freely suspended magnet always points in the north-south direction
Magnetic compass: uses and working principle
Finding directions using a compass
Making a magnet by rubbing (stroking method)
Making a magnet using electricity (simple electromagnet)
Demagnetisation: heating, hammering, dropping
Proper storage of magnets (keeper bars)
out_of_scope: Magnetic field lines and field patterns — Class 7-8
Earth's magnetic field in detail — Class 8
